--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> ... in terms=
 of profit/fitness the 
> result so far is about 40% higher than my previou=
s best strategy. 

Well, it's a good start!


> Part of the problem is that=
 although I have data for 521 companies, 
> these aren't 521 independent da=
ta sets because the price graph for a
lot 
> of these companies is very sim=
ilar.

Very good point. Another thing you need to deal with (and this is ve=
ry
tricky) is that there is an inherent bias the data set acquired by
obtai=
ning history: you don't have data on shares that are no longer
traded, eith=
er because of takeover, privatisation or just plain going
bust! So when you=
 acquire a historical data set, you're only getting
data for companies that=
 have existed - largely unchanged - over the
whole period. Don't forget sha=
re price changes due to stock splits,
either (Mann Group, to my certain kno=
wledge, have split 5 or 6 to 1
this year).

> One problem I envisage with l=
onger histories is that older data may be 
> fairly useless in evolving a t=
rading strategy for the present, since no 
> doubt automated trading and se=
mi-automatic analysis/trading has
probably 
> been progressing in leaps and=
 bounds in the last 5 years or so, thus 
> fundamentally altering the short=
 term dynamics of the markets. 

Maybe, but the bulk of the money in the ma=
rkets tends to be from
institutions such as pension fund managers, who have=
 to find somewhere
to invest for our retirement! Systems (IT ones) that man=
age
investments are probably less likely to be effecting large changes in
t=
he market. The rise and rise of the hedge fund may be starting to
have an i=
mpact, and the current environment where tidal waves of
private equity are =
washing over the market must be having some
different kind of impact as wel=
l.

I'm wondering if, to complicate your model nicely, you might provide
nu=
mbers from moving windows of different lengths: the long run, for
underlyin=
g stock value, and the short run (how short? dunno) to assess
current marke=
t "peculiarities".

> However 
> if that is the case it might actually show=
 up in experiments - e.g.
if a 
> strategy evolves that does really well fo=
r several years in a row and 
> then starts doing badly for a long period.
=

One would hope so. A combination of data windows might help model to
know =
when it's out of its depth.
 
> So on the whole it's very interesting that =
NEAT has found a strategy 
> that performs really well over the provided da=
ta set, but all this does 
> for now is provide food for thought for the ne=
xt round of
experimentation.

That's the name of the game, though, isn't it=
!


Mike
